modernLegacy.culturalImpact: Jade has been revered in China for over 8,000 years. The phrase 'gold has a price, jade is priceless' (ÈªÑÈáëÊúâ‰ª∑ÁéâÊó†‰ª∑) reflects its supreme cultural value. Jade objects are central to Chinese art, archaeology, and spiritual practice, from Neolithic ritual objects to modern talismans.

Jade Offerings
festivals.description: Jade discs (bi) and tubes (cong) were offered in rituals to communicate with heaven and earth

worshipPractices: Used in imperial seals, ritual vessels, burial suits, talismans, and as offerings to ancestors and deities. Believed to preserve the body after death and grant immortality to Daoist immortals

name: Jade
shortDescription: Sacred stone embodying virtue, purity, and immortality in Chinese culture

etymology.components: Áéâ (pictograph of three jade pieces strung together)

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Jade represents the pinnacle of Chinese philosophical and spiritual values. Its hardness symbolizes courage and justice; its luster represents charity; its translucence embodies heaven's purity; its immutability signifies wisdom. The stone bridges the gap between mortal and immortal, serving as both protective talisman and spiritual conduit.

associatedDeities.name: Xi Wangmu (Queen Mother of the West)

mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Jade has been revered in China for over 8,000 years. Jade objects are central to Chinese art, archaeology, and spiritual practice, from Neolithic ritual objects to modern talismans.

textReferences.context: Describes the ritual use of jade in ceremonies
Defines jade as 'the fairest of stones' embodying five virtues
Describes jade deposits and their mythological significance

originPoint.description: Jade working culture emerged in Neolithic China (Hongshan, Liangzhu cultures); nephrite and jadeite sources throughout China
originPoint.area: Yellow River and Yangtze River regions

longDescription: Jade (Áéâ, y√π) is the most sacred stone in Chinese mythology and culture, believed to embody the five virtues: charity, modesty, courage, justice, and wisdom. More precious than gold in ancient China, jade is associated with immortality, spiritual purity, and divine power. The stone comes in two main types: nephrite (ËΩØÁéâ) and jadeite (Á°¨Áéâ), with nephrite being the traditional Chinese jade. Jade is used in ritual objects, imperial seals, burial suits, and talismans, serving as a bridge between the earthly and celestial realms.

temporal.culturalContext: Confucian virtue symbolism; imperial authority; Daoist immortality connection; continuous jade culture

firstAttestation.description: Neolithic jade artifacts from Hongshan culture (c. 4700-2900 BCE); oracle bone inscriptions mention jade
